>How do I activate Windows?

>>Which version should I install?
>Education/Enterprise
Can disable telemetry and delay updates a year.
>LTSC / IoT LTSC
LTSC = 5 years support, VL/KMS only
IoT LTSC = 10 years support, HWID only
Comes with Win32 system apps, no MS Store, no feature updates, security updates only.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: 
wsreset -i


>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 10/2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC lasts until 2032.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89815977
Semigroup and its subclasses is not very related to Functor and its subclasses. An Alternative is a Monoid over an Applicative so that probably only makes sense if you understand both of those. MonadPlus is a lot like Alternative but specialized for Monads. Arrows are a more general computation than Monads but are not a superset. Functor is the most important typeclass to understand. So it should be more like:
Functor -> Applicative -> Monad
Semigroup -> Monoid -> Alternative -> MonadPlus
Foldable -> Traversable
Category -> Arrow
A lot of the lower classes are just generalized over some other class of Functor.

The solution to this stuff is Twitter implementing a Levenshtein algorithm for validating usernames.

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Levenshtein_distance

You would have a fast cache server with all twitter usernames in ram and you would query a Levenshtein distance between the new username and every existing username in the cache database. If an approximate match m is found greater than match M the user would not be able to choose that username.

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Approximate_string_matching

That would make it impossible to create a username that is exactly like an existing one except for a few characters. It would enforce completely original usernames.

Why would a thread "belong to" those who posted in it earlier?
Unless it's a debate forum where it would be rude to give yourself the last word on everything just due to the time passed (you should really start a new thread discussing them, not insert yourself as though you were a part of the debate), you should be able to tag onto a conversation.

If I want to post that my favorite FF7 team is Cloud, Barret, and Yuffie, why would I need to make an entirely new thread about it if there's already a "favorite team" thread, even if it's 25 years old?
Understanding of the underlying mechanics may mean that it's different from what others were picking on first release, but a reader should be able to follow it through the time differences, and there's no reason to keep it undisturbed in an archive that nobody will ever read. Bringing it back up can be interesting just for the anachronisms.

Still doesn't work I'm afraid.
If the package struct was defined in a repo, then for two different version of it you would have two different structs that just happen to share the name package.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89814559
>It's a simple binary: either you can have extensible packages that contain and reference lisp objects, or you can a less flexible version of packages that can be send between versions.
You can have both. It's not complex. Instead of using derivations, make a CLOS object that contains the relevant information. E.g.
(defclass package () 
  ((name :type string)
   (source :type some-origin-object)
   (build-exp :type cons :documentation "List of expressions to build the package")
   (inputs :type cons :documentation "List of package inputs")
   ...))

You can consider build-exp to be a list of G-expressions. This would mean that a package object could easily be serialized and deserialized. It'd be self-contained, so there would be no compatibility problems unless you redefined the package class (in which case you should be OK unless you removed a field). It's no less flexible, and you can implement all package modifications in terms of this single object. With a macro called say package you could use a similar build-system field that simply fills in the build expression.
>That's the reason they designed a system with both derivations and packages.
The reason is that it was much easier to compile package records to derivations than rewrite the daemon in Guile.
>You can't have something with both of the good properties, one comes at the cost of the other.
You listed two properties that have no relation with each other at all. You realize that reliably transmitting and storing objects is literally just serialization of some data, right? It's as trivial as things go. I don't see any justification for your claim.

threads.com: I don’t get it, what’s the point of proof oriented programming? I wrote the code, I already know what it does, that’s what unit testing is for. Do math nerds need to ruin everything with their grubby hands?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89815099
proofs == your program is supposedly and objectively sound (free of defects)
unit testing == parts of your program are largely correct, but only within the logic of the programmer who wrote the tests.
You want proofs for systems that matter, or for proving certain things about them for other people (compilers and their type system).
In F*'s case, it's attempting to implement a verified HTTPS and other things. So having a mechanical proof is important.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89815099
>I don’t get it, what’s the point of proof oriented programming? I wrote the code, I already know what it does, that’s what unit testing is for.
The point is that proofs can catch a far broader set of errors than unit testing can.

threads.com: Why are perl and php such kino languages /g/?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89811699
Like that anon >>89812269 said.
I don't know about php, but perl is very expressive and have mostly simple semantics.
I think the way it deal with lists compared to the other scripting language is underrated.
The fact that lists are expressions and that lists of lists are automatically flattened (of course you can make nested lists) makes it extremely easy to makes lists, without having to manually flatten them, or do type conversion (like .to_a in Ruby, list() in Python) or having to care about which built-in function to use (like in Python: push or extend?).
Functions are variadic by default. Is JavaScript you had to wait for ES6 to have that.
You only have 1 filter function which is grep. In Ruby you have grep, grep_v, filter, select and you never know which one to use. Python has filter but the syntax for writing lambdas is horrible.
There is only 1 map function, wether in Ruby you have each, map and map!. In JavaScript you have map and forEach.
And 1 sort function.
The fact that parentheses are not required, except for enforcing precedence, also makes working with lists and function in general easier and easy to read.

Perl has goto, contrary to the other ones, and also contrary to the other ones, it has explicit references (high level pointers) which mean you can pass variable by reference or by value, it's your choice, and you can program in the same logic as in C when you need to, which make perl really good as a prototype language if you have a C project.
So Perl mogs again the others when it comes to imperative programming.

Perl as closures, like all the other ones, except that they are actually usable because they have an excellent syntax for it. do over sub, analogously to let over lambda in lisp. Both Ruby and Python syntax for closure is atrocious.
I just discovered it recently myself, but perl do have tail calls (there is a special syntax for it) contrary to most other scripting languages.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89811699

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>89813392
Finally, it is King for string manipulation thanks to its exceptionally well integrated regex engine, who has also good performance characteristics. Good lisp manipulation and functions is also practical. And the final nail, you never have to care about or do explicit type conversion. It always just works, and there is never ambiguity because arithmetic and string operators are distinct, which means there is no bullshit to wether + means addition or concatenation.

Tl;dr Perl is better than the other scripting languages for string, regexes, lists, function programming, and imperative programming.
It is also the best terminal language and it's not even a competition.
